    • Method Detail

      • addChild

        public <V> things.thing.Thing<V> addChild(things.thing.Thing<?> parent,
                                          things.thing.Thing<V> child)
        Description copied from interface: ThingWriter

        Adds a parent-child relationship for the two provided objects.

        Internally, a parent reference should be stored on the child object, not the other way around. Since this particular writer might not have the ability to ensure the persistence of the parent thing.

        Specified by:
        addChild in interface ThingWriter
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent
        child - the child
        Returns:
        the child (most likely the same object as the input-child, but can’t be guaranteed

      • deleteAllThings

        public void deleteAllThings()

      • deleteThing

        public boolean deleteThing(String id,
                           Optional<String> thingType,
                           Optional<String> key)
        Description copied from interface: ThingWriter

        Delete the thing with the specified id.

        The Type and Key arguments are optional. They are used to speed up finding the appropriate ThingWriter (using ThingWriters), without having to invoke all of them.

        Specified by:
        deleteThing in interface ThingWriter
        Parameters:
        id - the id of the thing
        thingType - the (optional) type
        key - the (optional) key
        Returns:
        whether the thing was successfully deleted (true) or not (false)

      • saveThing

        public <V> things.thing.Thing<V> saveThing(things.thing.Thing<V> t)
        Description copied from interface: ThingWriter

        Persists this thing.

        Specified by:
        saveThing in interface ThingWriter
        Parameters:
        t - the thing
        Returns:
        the reference to the persisted thing. It is advised to always use that from the moment of calling this method, it can’t be guaranteed that the old thing is not obsolete
